Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Control of Processes Actuated with Mobile Radiant Sources

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this faculty early career development (CAREER) award is to conduct research on the estimation and control of distributed parameter processes employing mobile radiant actuators. The project targets energy-efficient radiative drying and curing processes for large scale manufacturing lines. The approach is to i) identify reduced models that resolve the processes into the main energy transmission and state evolution phases in search of a unified analytical framework, ii) seek effective state estimation schemes that overcome the challenges associated with the lack of suitable non-contact sensing for key process states, iii) develop closed-loop control strategies that coordinate the flux levels and the trajectory of the radiant actuators while optimizing energy use and productivity without sacrificing product quality, and, iv) conduct experimental verifications using a prototype radiative drying/curing system along with analysis of processed and in-process samples via FTIR, AFM and other tomography techniques.

This research will potentially play a transformative role in reducing total energy use and CO2 emissions from manufacturing lines. Addressing the fundamental problem of controlling moving radiant sources will also impact other processes (e.g. robotic welding and spray forming) and applications in pollution mitigation and medical radiotherapy. Furthermore, despite the numerous applications, the control of distributed parameter systems is rarely covered in the controls education curriculum at many institutions. This project will help advance education in the topic through a new course on distributed parameter control and interactive laboratory demonstrations. Planned education and outreach efforts themed around ?control for energy efficiency? include: interfacing with undergraduate research opportunity sites and Clemson?s Creative Inquiry program to involve undergraduates, including minorities and women, in the research; holding and taking part in summer science teacher workshops and ?success camps?; and, disseminating research results. The project will also leverage existing collaborations for technology transfer of promising findings to the automotive and aerospace industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were 1) to study and devise control systems related enablers for industrial processes employing radiant actuators (ultra-violet curing, infra-red drying, laser-aided deposition) that impact the energy use and product quality from these large scale manufacturing processes, and 2) to train students in control-oriented modeling and experimental tools via participation in the research, eduation and outreach activities.

The first technical challenge addressed is the throughcure or radiation attentuation problem prevalent in the use of ultra-violet light for curing thick films. The project team offered two solutions for the same: 1) Mathematically derived model-based feedback compensation schemes, and; 2) Devised a novel layering and curing scheme to which a hybrid (discrete/continuous) process modeling view is adopted and explicit process optimization criteria were derived. The latter idea, which we called stepped-concurrent curing (SCC), has been demonstrated to reduce curing time/energy needs for making thick parts both via computational modeling and experiments. Furthermore, to address the associated difficulty arising from lack of suitable non-contact sensing of cure states across depth, the project team has also devised distributed state estimation schemes that take into account the attenuation phenomena.

For the drying application, which involves phase change phenomena coupled to mass and energy transfer, the associated descriptive models are highly complex and nonlinear. These required the use of elaborate model-reduction techniques based on which distributed state (moisture content, temperature) estimation and robust predictive control schemes have been proposed and demonstrated. Robustness is a key consideration given the uncertainities prevalent in the modeling and sensing of this industrial process.

The project has also made contributions in the modeling and control of laser-aided powder deposition processes, which similarly involve a mobile radiant source and complex multi-physical interactions. The contributions include 1)PDE-based optimization of melt-interface tracking, 2) control-oriented multi-input multi-out modeling of laser-aided powder deposition processes, and 3) robust and predictive control of these processes. Another closely-related application that leveraged the activities in this project is the distributed state estimation of electrochemical batteries. 

The methods and results from the contributions described above are primarily disseminated through over 24 peer-reviewed archival journal publications and conference proceeding papers.

The project has involved at least 4 graduate students directly in the research, education and outreach activities. Two doctoral students supported by the grant are now gainfully employed in R&D positions in industry. The PI and the graduate students have also organized and participated in Summer Scholar programs with hands on demonstration excercises for high school students in their week long visits to the PI's department. The PI has successfully leveraged this faculty CAREER development grant to expand collaborations with outreach to a number of companies and other funding agencies. A total of 7 doctoral and 15 Masters students have been mentored by the PI during this time. All of them are gainfully empolyed in R&D positions industry and 1 has accepted a tenure-track faculty position in academia.
